title: Federer Endorses Alcaraz's Quest for Career Grand Slam at Australian Open
summary: Roger Federer, a retired tennis legend, has publicly expressed his hope that Carlos Alcaraz can win the Australian Open and become the youngest man to complete the career Grand Slam. Alcaraz, aged 22 and currently world number one, aims to add the Melbourne title to his existing two Wimbledon, two French Open, and two US Open victories. Federer, who achieved his own career Grand Slam in 2009, acknowledged the difficulty of this feat, comparing it to golfer Rory McIlroy's pursuit of the Masters. Speaking at a news conference in Melbourne Park, Federer emphasized that completing the set at a young age would be 'crazy' and special for the sport. Alcaraz is engaged in a compelling rivalry with Jannik Sinner, with the pair splitting the last eight Grand Slam titles and contesting the past three finals. Federer praised their progression and ball-striking abilities, while also wishing them injury-free careers. Federer is in Melbourne for a ceremony honoring his legacy, marking his first visit since 2020.

background_read: The career Grand Slam in tennis is a prestigious accomplishment where a player wins all four major tournaments: Australian Open, French Open, Wimbledon, and US Open. Roger Federer, a Swiss tennis icon, completed his in 2009 with a French Open win, after already securing the others by 2004. Carlos Alcaraz, a rising Spanish star, has quickly amassed six major titles and aims to add the Australian Open to become the youngest to achieve this feat. His rivalry with Jannik Sinner mirrors historic duels like Federer-Nadal-Djokovic, adding drama to the sport. Federer's endorsement highlights the passing of the torch in tennis, emphasizing the importance of youth, health, and competition in sustaining the game's legacy.
